abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Road Maintenance
            Project for Lao were as follows: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned: A paradigm shift in GOL policy where the
            preservation of the existing network would receive priority
            over its expansion is fundamental to the success of the
            program. Appropriate axle load legislation, effectively
            enforced, offers considerable advantages to network
            sustainability. While focusing capacity building on training
            of individuals' in-house technical capabilities remains
            important, addressing institutional incentives and defining
            organizational responsibilities is necessary to achieving
            sustainable capacity. A second phase of the APL is under
            implementation and will (a) bring the road
            cost-recovery-based financing closer to a sustainable level;
            (b) enhance the management systems and extend them to cover
            the management of both national and local road networks over
            the whole country; and (c) expand the coverage of heavy
            transport control throughout the country.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Maintenance Project for Laos
            promotes the sustainable preservation of the national road
            network (NRN) through the development and implementation of
            financing and management maintenance systems; and designs
            and tests, in four selected provinces, financing and
            management systems for the sustainable maintenance of the
            local road network (LRN). There are eight project
            components. The first component finances periodic
            maintenance works on various maintainable sections of the
            NRN and LRN. The second component finances routine emergency
            works. The third component supports a strategy to reduce
            overloading on the road network and provides works, weighing
            equipment and specialized services that promote policy
            reforms, partnership between the government and the
            transport industry, and capacity building. The fourth
            component completes the establishment of the road management
            system. The fifth component consists of providing
            specialized consultants that will assist the Road
            Maintenance Advisory Board and its Secretariat in carrying
            out their activities. The sixth component develops
            institutional capacity to manage projects by improving
            project preparation, execution, and monitoring, and by
            developing a strategy to improve the performance of the
            local contracting and consulting industry. The eighth
            component fosters the involvement of road users and
            beneficiaries in delivering and managing road maintenance activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Laos - Road Maintenance Program Project -
            resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement plan has been prepared
            to ensure that unforeseen impacts, as a result of the Road
            Maintenance Program Project, be compensated in accordance to
            resettlement guidelines. In order to minimize resettlement,
            cash compensation will be provided for lost land at
            replacement cost, or market value for permanent loss of
            arable land, and, a minimum cash compensation, equivalent to
            ten percent value of the affected asset, will be paid for
            temporary loss of arable land. Residential land compensation
            will be paid in cash at replacement cost, or market value.
            Commercial land, where business premises are partially
            affected, will be compensated in cash at market value, and,
            structures partially affected will be compensated in cash
            for the affected portion/assets, including assistance in
            restoration of remaining structures. Crops affected by
            permanent/temporary land acquisition, will be compensated in
            cash at market value. Business and other income losses, will
            be compensated in cash, calculated on the basis of tax
            declaration per six months for permanent losses, while
            temporary losses will be calculated on the basis of tax
            declaration for the duration of the impact. Grievance
            mechanisms will be established to minimize potential
            resettlement problems.

repnme.cdata!:
Laos - Road Maintenance Program Project :
            environmental guidelines

abstracts.cdata!:
These environmental guidelines refer to
            several aspects of the project road planning, design, and
            construction, since potential environmental adversity may
            occur, and, stipulates that if major impacts are identified,
            an environmental assessment will be prepared, with
            extensive, and detailed screening criteria. Environmental
            effects, and mitigation measures are as follows. Road
            planning, and design should take into account the terrain,
            and traffic volume, to minimize excessive earthworks, and
            disruption to local people; which should include an
            appropriate number of bridges, and culverts, and, the
            effects of road widening on existing roadside tree-lines,
            could be reduced by widening only one side, retaining trees
            on the other. Engineering design should avoid adversity on
            natural habitats, wildlife, and forestry, as well as
            cultural heritage sites. Installation of sound barriers, and
            protective forest belts, will abate noise, and air pollution
            as a result of construction, while bituminous surfacing will
            prevent dust pollution, namely on gravel roads sections
            traversing settlements. Provisions regarding safety, include
            traffic signaling, safe crossings, and fences. Vegetative
            propagation will preserve the buffer zone between the road,
            and surface water bodies, and, adequate design of culverts,
            and road drainage will be ensured to minimize flooding, and
            adversity on existing irrigation systems, prevent water
            contamination, and contain soil erosion. Resettlement issues
            are specifically addressed in the Resettlement Action Plan (RAP).
